title: Psoriasis Complications
author: Kristen Fischer

sections.heading: What Are Psoriasis Complications?
content: Psoriasis complications go beyond the way skin may look. You may have a wide range of other issues, like heart disease, kidney disease, joint problems, or depression, as a result of the disease.
Secondary infections also are a common complication in people with psoriasis, as any open wound can make it harder to treat the lesions.
How common are psoriasis complications?
About 5% of Americans live with psoriasis , according to estimates. Not all of them may have complications.

Psoriasis can disrupt your quality of life on its own or due to other issues that commonly come with it. Those with moderate to severe cases of psoriasis – about 25% of all psoriasis patients – report negative impacts on their quality of life. About 60% of people say the disease creates a large problem in their lives.

Secondary infections also are a common complication in people with psoriasis, as any open wound can make it harder to treat the lesions.
How common are psoriasis complications?
About 5% of Americans live with psoriasis , according to estimates. Not all of them may have complications.

Psoriasis can disrupt your quality of life on its own or due to other issues that commonly come with it. Those with moderate to severe cases of psoriasis – about 25% of all psoriasis patients – report negative impacts on their quality of life. About 60% of people say the disease creates a large problem in their lives.

sections.heading: Why Do Psoriasis Complications Happen?
content: Psoriasis is a chronic, systemic inflammatory disease that affects your immune system. The ongoing inflammation is likely to blame for some of the complications.

content_blocks.text: Psoriasis is a chronic, systemic inflammatory disease that affects your immune system. The ongoing inflammation is likely to blame for some of the complications.

sections.heading: Most Common Psoriasis Complications
content: There are several complications that can happen as a result of having psoriasis or psoriatic arthritis.
Psoriatic arthritis

Psoriatic arthritis (PsA) is a complication of psoriasis that happens in about 30% of people who have psoriasis. It’s a serious complication because it can be disabling, as it causes joint pain, swelling, and stiffness.
Typically, people have psoriasis first, and then psoriatic arthritis emerges years after.
Like psoriasis, psoriatic arthritis can flare up and then die down on a rolling basis.
What can you do?
bullets: There's no cure for psoriatic arthritis, but you can manage symptoms and stop joint damage that can become permanent if not treated. And if you can lower the inflammation that comes with PsA, you may be able to avoid other conditions caused by inflammation.

The best way to do this is to see a rheumatologist to discuss treatment options. These include prescription and nonprescription drugs and remedies, as well as oral medicines and injectables that can slow down the progression of the disease.

Psoriatic arthritis

What can you do?

items: There's no cure for psoriatic arthritis, but you can manage symptoms and stop joint damage that can become permanent if not treated. And if you can lower the inflammation that comes with PsA, you may be able to avoid other conditions caused by inflammation.

The best way to do this is to see a rheumatologist to discuss treatment options. These include prescription and nonprescription drugs and remedies, as well as oral medicines and injectables that can slow down the progression of the disease.

sections.heading: Heart disease
content: Psoriatic arthritis and psoriasis both raise your chance of having diseases in your heart and blood vessels, especially if your psoriatic disease is more severe. People with severe psoriasis are at the highest risk. They’re almost 60% more likely to have a heart attack and 40% more likely to have a stroke. If you have severe PsA, you’re more likely to have heart disease that could be deadly.

content_blocks.text: Psoriatic arthritis and psoriasis both raise your chance of having diseases in your heart and blood vessels, especially if your psoriatic disease is more severe. People with severe psoriasis are at the highest risk. They’re almost 60% more likely to have a heart attack and 40% more likely to have a stroke. If you have severe PsA, you’re more likely to have heart disease that could be deadly.

content: Psoriatic disease raises your chances of having high blood pressure, belly fat, and high cholesterol. All three are linked to higher heart disease risk. Chronic inflammation in psoriatic disease causes you to get these heart-related risks.
What can you do?
bullets: Talk to your doctor about screening for signs of diseases in your heart and blood vessels, like high blood pressure or high cholesterol.
To lower your odds of heart attacks and strokes, treat your psoriatic disease and get inflammation under control as soon as possible.
Quit smoking. Tobacco smoking makes drugs that treat psoriatic disease, such as biologics, work less effectively. Smoking is a major risk factor for heart disease, too.

Maintain a healthy weight. People with PsA may have more severe disease if they’re obese , and obesity also makes you more likely to have heart disease. Excess weight and body fat also make psoriasis more severe. Losing weight can reverse that effect.

content_blocks.text: Psoriatic disease raises your chances of having high blood pressure, belly fat, and high cholesterol. All three are linked to higher heart disease risk. Chronic inflammation in psoriatic disease causes you to get these heart-related risks.
What can you do?

items: Talk to your doctor about screening for signs of diseases in your heart and blood vessels, like high blood pressure or high cholesterol.

Quit smoking. Tobacco smoking makes drugs that treat psoriatic disease, such as biologics, work less effectively. Smoking is a major risk factor for heart disease, too.

Maintain a healthy weight. People with PsA may have more severe disease if they’re obese , and obesity also makes you more likely to have heart disease. Excess weight and body fat also make psoriasis more severe. Losing weight can reverse that effect.

sections.heading: Diabetes
content: Psoriatic disease also makes you more likely to get type 2 diabetes . If you have severe psoriasis, your risk of getting diabetes goes up by 30%. More people with psoriatic arthritis, especially women, have diabetes, compared to those without psoriatic disease.

Chronic inflammation is likely to blame. Both psoriatic disease and diabetes involve inflammation throughout your body. It can cause insulin resistance, which is an early sign of diabetes. Some hormones, especially in women with psoriatic disease, may be linked to diabetes risk.
What can you do?
Psoriasis eye complications

If you have psoriatic disease, you may get uveitis, a rare type of eye inflammation. Symptoms include blurred vision, redness, light sensitivity, floaters in your vision, and pain. It can happen in one or both eyes and start suddenly.
bullets: Get screened for diabetes, especially if you’re female. If you notice any early signs of diabetes, like being extra thirsty or having blurry vision, let your doctor know right away.
Eat a healthy diet, get regular exercise, and manage your weight to help prevent diabetes. If you’re overweight or obese, you’re much more likely to get diabetes.

content_blocks.text: Psoriasis eye complications

If you have psoriatic disease, you may get uveitis, a rare type of eye inflammation. Symptoms include blurred vision, redness, light sensitivity, floaters in your vision, and pain. It can happen in one or both eyes and start suddenly.

content: PsA, psoriasis, and uveitis all involve inflammation. Certain common genes may link uveitis with psoriatic disease too.
What can you do?
Mental health

Psoriatic disease also makes you more likely to have mood issues like depression . Some people with PsA or psoriasis may get depressed because they have a chronic illness that affects their everyday life. If you have more severe psoriatic symptoms, like inflamed joints or fatigue, it could be more severe. PsA seems to carry a higher risk of depression than psoriasis.
Research shows that people with psoriatic arthritis who are unemployed are more likely to be depressed, so how your disease affects your life may be a strong factor in your mental health.
Inflammation plays a role in depression, too. Higher levels of cytokines, proteins in your blood that drive inflammation in psoriatic disease, are also seen in depression.
bullets: Get yearly eye exams to look for early signs of eye inflammation or damage. If you notice any possible uveitis symptoms or changes in your vision, see an ophthalmologist , a doctor who specializes in eye diseases.

content_blocks.text: PsA, psoriasis, and uveitis all involve inflammation. Certain common genes may link uveitis with psoriatic disease too.
What can you do?

items: Get yearly eye exams to look for early signs of eye inflammation or damage. If you notice any possible uveitis symptoms or changes in your vision, see an ophthalmologist , a doctor who specializes in eye diseases.

content_blocks.text: Mental health

Psoriatic disease also makes you more likely to have mood issues like depression . Some people with PsA or psoriasis may get depressed because they have a chronic illness that affects their everyday life. If you have more severe psoriatic symptoms, like inflamed joints or fatigue, it could be more severe. PsA seems to carry a higher risk of depression than psoriasis.
Research shows that people with psoriatic arthritis who are unemployed are more likely to be depressed, so how your disease affects your life may be a strong factor in your mental health.
Inflammation plays a role in depression, too. Higher levels of cytokines, proteins in your blood that drive inflammation in psoriatic disease, are also seen in depression.

sections.heading: What can you do?
content: Psoriasis complications in your gut

If you have a psoriatic disease, you could get an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) like Crohn’s disease or ulcerative colitis (UC). Your risk of Crohn’s is higher than your risk of getting UC, but both are possible.
Crohn’s and psoriatic disease may be caused by the same altered genes. Inflammation is involved in both diseases. Gut bacteria might trigger inflammation in your digestive system and joints.
What can you do?
bullets: Treating your psoriatic disease may ease depression symptoms. You may need psychological counseling to help.

If you notice the signs of IBD, like diarrhea , blood in your poop, or belly cramps, let your doctor know. They may be able to suggest changes to your diet that ease IBD symptoms or help you manage them.

items: Treating your psoriatic disease may ease depression symptoms. You may need psychological counseling to help.

content: There are several types of psoriasis, and your complications may vary based on the kind of psoriasis you have. Along with the psoriasis complications above, these complications may be based on the type of psoriasis you have.

content_blocks.text: There are several types of psoriasis, and your complications may vary based on the kind of psoriasis you have. Along with the psoriasis complications above, these complications may be based on the type of psoriasis you have.

sections.heading: Plaque psoriasis complications
content: The scaly patches can cause an altered skin appearance, itching, and a poor quality of life. And treatment side effects may be common in plaque psoriasis , which is the most common form of the disease.
Inverse psoriasis complications
This form happens in the folds of your skin, but there are no scaly patches. Skin irritation can lead to infections, and the condition may be painful.
Scalp psoriasis complications
This kind of psoriasis can cause hair loss and may be painful.
Guttate psoriasis complications

Guttate psoriasis can come on suddenly, like after an infection, and is common in people under 30 years old. Guttate psoriasis may clear up after treatment, especially when people use phototherapy. But it can become a lifelong condition or turn into plaque psoriasis.
Pustular psoriasis complications

Specific complications for this type of psoriasis, which features pus-filled bumps, include low calcium, hyperthermia, liver damage, acute kidney failure, malnutrition, and sepsis (blood poisoning from bacteria).
Erythrodermic psoriasis complications

Inverse psoriasis complications

Pustular psoriasis complications

Specific complications for this type of psoriasis, which features pus-filled bumps, include low calcium, hyperthermia, liver damage, acute kidney failure, malnutrition, and sepsis (blood poisoning from bacteria).
Erythrodermic psoriasis complications

content: Though it’s a rare type of psoriasis, the complications can be serious or fatal. It can affect how well your body can control its temperature.
Nail psoriasis complications
Complications can come from treatment or the natural progress of the condition. People may have infections, functional disability, and psychological distress. The nails may crumble or fall off.

content_blocks.text: Though it’s a rare type of psoriasis, the complications can be serious or fatal. It can affect how well your body can control its temperature.
Nail psoriasis complications
Complications can come from treatment or the natural progress of the condition. People may have infections, functional disability, and psychological distress. The nails may crumble or fall off.

sections.heading: Other Psoriasis Complications
content: Metabolic syndrome involves high blood pressure and blood sugar, abnormal cholesterol levels, and excess fat. Cancer (specifically lymphoma , a cancer in the lymph system), sleep apnea, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease ( COPD ), kidney disease, and liver disease are common in people with psoriatic disease.
Temporary skin color changes and other autoimmune diseases like celiac disease are also seen often with psoriasis.

content_blocks.text: Metabolic syndrome involves high blood pressure and blood sugar, abnormal cholesterol levels, and excess fat. Cancer (specifically lymphoma , a cancer in the lymph system), sleep apnea, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease ( COPD ), kidney disease, and liver disease are common in people with psoriatic disease.
Temporary skin color changes and other autoimmune diseases like celiac disease are also seen often with psoriasis.

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Psoriasis isn’t just a cosmetic issue, it’s an immune disease that can get worse over time if you don’t treat it.
When you manage symptoms, that can help you feel better, improve your health, and keep psoriasis from getting worse.

sections.heading: Psoriasis Complications FAQs
content: Can psoriasis affect internal organs?
Psoriasis can cause inflammation in the body that can affect organs in your body.

content_blocks.text: Can psoriasis affect internal organs?
Psoriasis can cause inflammation in the body that can affect organs in your body.

sections.heading: What’s a neurological complication of psoriasis?
content: There can be several, such as epilepsy, multiple sclerosis, and Parkinson’s disease.
What are patients with psoriasis at greater risk for?

If you have psoriasis, you have a higher risk than those without it for cancer, diabetes, Crohn's disease, metabolic syndrome, obesity, osteoporosis, liver disease, uveitis (inflammation of the middle of the eye), and kidney disease.
Can you get sepsis from psoriasis?
Yes. Sepsis (blood poisoning from bacteria) can be a psoriasis complication. One study reported it was the most common diagnosis in people hospitalized for psoriasis.
What are the long-term complications of psoriasis?
There are many, but psoriatic arthritis is a big one. About 30% of people with psoriasis go on to have psoriatic arthritis, or PsA. The disease can be serious and disabling.
Do people with psoriasis get sick easier?

If you have psoriasis, you have a higher chance of other autoimmune diseases that can have a negative impact on your immune system and your body’s ability to defend itself. Psoriasis is thought to be caused in part by a problem in the immune system, and other triggers can cause symptoms to flare up.

meta_description: Could having psoriatic arthritis or psoriasis put you at risk of other health problems? Psoriatic disease can cause complications that affect your heart, bowels, eyes, and even your mental health. Learn why this happens and what you can do.
